Description: South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim, reconstructed from numerous fragments and added plaster; interior: reserved band at top of lip, glazed black below; exterior: narrow black line at top of lip; lip and handle zone reserved with band between; glazed below; exterior surface of handles glazed; reserved on underside; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type A2
Curator's comments: The cup includes British Museum 1886,0401.309. Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd, it does find parallels with his South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 5C or Type 9A. These cups closely follow the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups and coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18) and Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type A2 or B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Type 5 cups are few at Naukratis whereas there are numerous examples of Type 9 cups. Both types were common drinking vessels found in Greeks sanctuaries, including the sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.088) (Phase 3)
